text: Judges chapter number seven, as you know, our Missions Conference is just a couple of weeks away and it's my prayer and my desire that we will be prepared spiritually for the special conference. Obviously, our ultimate desire is that the Lord Jesus Christ alone would be exalted and magnified through all that's done. And last week on Sunday evening, in preparation for our Missions Conference, we examined a portion of Exodus chapter number three. He was gonna bring them out so that he could bring them in, but we find that he's gonna use Moses and God's plan includes God's people. And I'm thankful for that. The second wonderful truth from that passage that we focused on was that God promises to be with his people as they do what he has commanded them to do. And then you find that the Bible tells us that there arose another generation and this generation that rose up, unfortunately they did not continue to serve the Lord. And because of their idolatry, because of their disobedience, because of their wickedness, God judged them. And what God did is he raised up certain people groups to judge his own people. And he would raise up these particular groups of people to judge the children of Israel because of their disobedience. The children of Israel were not given a free pass because they were God's chosen people, no. They had been given the responsibility to live according to the precepts that God had prescribed. And he gave them many times a warning. If you do this, here will be the blessings. But if you obey not, here will be the judgments or the curses. And we find that in the book of Judges, what would happen is a group of people would really oppress the children of Israel and they would be under judgment. And God would graciously raise up a judge and judge that people group that had been oppressing the children of Israel. And then the children of Israel, after a little while, they would backslide right back into idolatry and so on and so forth. We've been quickened by the grace of God. Verse 18, and all things are of God, who hath reconciled us to Himself by Jesus Christ. What a joy to know that you've been reconciled. The sin of humanity is what put us at variance, but Jesus Christ said, I will pay for that sin so that we might be reconciled. It says this, that all things are of God, verse 18, who hath reconciled us to Himself by Jesus Christ. And this evening, if you're saved by the blood of Christ, you've been reconciled to God through salvation. But notice it says, and hath given to us the ministry of reconciliation. So he's now entrusted us with this ministry of reconciliation. It's interesting in chapter number four of the book of 2 Corinthians, he says this in Number one, therefore, seeing we have this ministry, as we have received mercy, we faint not. We find that God has given to us, as we look throughout the pages of this book of 2 Corinthians, this ministry. Here in chapter number five, speaking about the ministry of reconciliation, and I'm thankful that God enables us, and we do not have to faint to lose heart, to not know we can be renewed in our inner man, according to verse 16 of chapter four. But notice, as we consider this ministry that God has given to us, he says in chapter number four, that if our gospel be hidden, it is hidden to them that are lost. He tells us that in whom the God of this world hath blinded the minds of them which believe not, lest the light of the glorious gospel of Christ, who is the image of God, should shine unto them. There is a spiritual battle that's taking place. The God of this world, Satan, hath blinded the minds of them that believe not. Why? Because he wants them to stay lost. He doesn't want them to be saved. And then we find that the Bible tells us that we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus, the Lord. He tells us in verse number seven that we have this treasure in earth and vessels, that the excellency of the power may be of God, and not of us. Back to chapter five, he says that we've been given this ministry of reconciliation at the end of verse 18, and verse 19, to wit, that God was in Christ reconciling the world unto himself, not imputing their trespasses unto them, and hath committed unto us the word of reconciliation. Now, verse 20, now then, we are ambassadors for Christ. As though God did beseech you by us, we pray you in Christ's stead, be ye reconciled to God. Ambassadors. Ambassadors, representatives. You have an ambassador from the United States that goes to another country. They have one duty, to represent the U.S. in whatever territory, whatever country it is that they go, they're to represent the United States of America in that territory, in that country. I said this at the beginning of the service, not part of the message, but at the beginning of the service, this world is not my home, I'm just passing through. I'm a pilgrim and a stranger, and if you're saved by the grace of God, you're a pilgrim and a stranger too, you're heaven bound, our citizenship is in heaven, but God has left us here on this earth, we happen to be physically in the United States of America, as his ambassadors. So what is it that we're representing? We're representing his kingdom, we're preaching his gospel, we're given this ministry of reconciliation. If we do not understand the responsibility that has been assigned to us, there's no possibility that we're ever going to embrace it, yet fulfill it. And so we must understand the responsibility, and then we embrace that responsibility and say, God would use us to be his representatives. God would use us to tell someone else how they too could go to heaven. It's absolutely amazing that God would use us. Thinking about all of the possible things that God could have done, he could have used angels, he could have, you start filling in the blanks of what he could, but he decided to use us. And the question tonight, how are we doing fulfilling the responsibility? As we looked at the passage of Scripture in the book of Judges, the Bible says every man in his place, understanding that God has a place for us. And how are we doing fulfilling the responsibility that God has given to us? Have we embraced it? Have we ignored it? Have we fill in the blank? But how are we doing? Because God has given us a responsibility. And we must recognize this evening that yes, ultimately to bring honor and glory to God, and we can do that in a variety of ways, but according very clearly to John 15, when we bear fruit, it brings glory to God. Very plainly and very clearly. And so this evening, every man in his place, I wonder tonight, as we would take just a few moments to examine ourselves, have a time of invitation, if we truly allow the Spirit of God to work in our hearts and our lives, to really evaluate how we're doing in this area of the ministry that God has given to us. Because he left us here for a purpose, and he left us here to be his ambassadors, his representatives, and there are lost people that potentially only you will come in contact with, that God will give you the opportunity to share with them the glorious gospel. It may not be that your preacher ever has the opportunity to meet them or talk with them. It may simply be that you are the one that God has placed in their lives, and he's given to you the ministry of reconciliation. Let's pray. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. We thank you for the account in the book of Judges, having the opportunity to see that passage and that event and to understand those 300 men and their fulfillment of their responsibility that had been given to them. Every man was in his place. God, as we seek to, from that passage of Scripture, make application in our own lives with regard to the ministry that you've given to us and the call that you've placed upon our lives, for every child of God, anyone that's a new creature, anyone that's saved by the grace of God, that we are your ambassadors, that you have committed to us the ministry of reconciliation. You've promised to go with us, to be with us. You've promised that your word will not return void. You promised that your word will accomplish. You promised that your word is powerful, and the gospel is the power of God unto salvation to everyone that believeth. God, I pray tonight, in these few moments of invitation, that you'd help us to evaluate our lives. Lord, that you would help us to be yielded and surrendered. Help us to not only understand and embrace, but Lord, help us to fulfill the responsibility that you have given to us. We'll thank you for it. In Christ's name, we pray. Would you stand with me? Heads are bowed, eyes are closed. Kimberly's gonna play quietly on the piano, and as she does, the altar is open.
